title: Hammer v. Hammer
text:
THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Shirley Hammer, Appellant,
				v.
				Howard Hammer, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â RollyÂ  W.Â  Jacobs, Family Court Judge
Stephen S. Bartlett, Family Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2008-MO-012
Heard January 8, 2008 â€“ Filed March 10,
  2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


	
		
			
				A.
  Mattison Bogan, Timothy E. Madden, and Reid T. Sherard, all of Nelson, Mullins,
  Riley & Scarborough, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				James
  T. McLaren, and C. Dixon Lee, III, of McLaren & Lee, of Columbia, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  WALLER: Â These are consolidated appeals from family court orders which a) disqualified
  attorney J. Mark Taylor from representing Appellant, Shirley Hammer, in the
  underlying action for separate maintenance and support; and b) denied
  Appellantâ€™s motions for a de novo trial or in the alternative to
  reconsider or amend the order disqualifying her attorney.Â  We affirm in part
  and reverse in part.Â Â   
FACTS
Appellant,
  Shirley Hammer (Wife), and Respondent, Howard Hammer (Husband), were married in
  September 1998, and have two small children.Â Â  Wife filed an action for
  separate maintenance and support in September 2005.Â  Wife was represented by attorney
  J. Mark Taylor. Â 
Upon learning of Taylorâ€™s representation of Wife on September 2,
  2005, Husband immediately objected to Taylorâ€™s representation on the ground
  that Taylorâ€™s law partner, Jake Moore, had previously represented Husband in a
  collections matter against a former girlfriend.Â  The collections matter ended
  in 1995, three years before the parties married.Â  Taylor concluded there was no
  impermissible conflict.Â  Husband took no further action to have Wifeâ€™s attorney
  relieved.Â   
A Temporary Consent Order was entered on September 14, 2005,
  stipulating to custody, visitation, and financial matters.Â  Approximately 15
  monthsÂ  later, on December 8, 2006, Wife filed a Complaint and Rule to Show
  Cause seeking to have Husband held in contempt for failing to comply with the
  Temporary Consent Order.Â  Husband responded and moved to have attorney J. Mark
  Taylor disqualified from representing Wife due to his partnership with Jake
  Moore.Â  Husband contended Taylor had imputed knowledge of his â€œemotional
  makeupâ€ and that the prior matter involved â€œinterpersonal relationships and
  other matters of a private, confidential and personal nature among other
  things.â€Â   
A
  hearing was held before Judge Rolly Jacobs on April 11, 2007.Â  At the
  conclusion of the hearing, Judge Jacobs orally ruled that Taylor was
  disqualified from representing Wife due to his partnership in the firm which
  previously represented Husband in the collection action against the former
  girlfriend.Â  Judge Jacobs instructed Husbandâ€™s attorney, James McLaren, to
  prepare an order, which he did.Â  After being reviewed by both sides, a proposed
  order was mailed to Judge Jacobs on Friday, May 4, 2007.Â  Judge Jacobs signed
  the order on Tuesday, May 8, 2007; he then forwarded the order to McLaren for
  filing.Â  The order arrived at McLarenâ€™s office on Friday, May 11, 2007, a day
  when McLaren was in Court in Greenville.Â Â  Judge Jacobs died unexpectedly on
  Sunday, May 13, 2007.Â  McLaren filed the order with the Richland County Clerk
  of Court on Tuesday, May 15, 2007.
On May
  18, 2007, Wife filed a Motion for a De Novo Hearing and/or
  Reconsideration, Alteration, or Amendment alleging Judge Jacobsâ€™ order was void
  because it had not been filed at the time of his death.Â  Judge Stephen Bartlett
  held a hearing on May 31, 2007.Â  Judge Bartlett held that, pursuant to Rule 63,
  SCRCP, Judge Jacobsâ€™ order had been issued at the time of his death, such that
  his order was a valid order and therefore he, Judge Bartlett, was without
  authority or jurisdiction to alter or amend Judge Jacobsâ€™ order.Â  Judge
  Bartlett declined to consider the affidavits of Wife filed subsequent to the
  hearing before Judge Jacobs, and declined to address the merits of Wifeâ€™s
  contention that her attorney had been improperly disqualified.Â  Wife appeals
  both orders.[1]  
ISSUES
1.Â  Did
  Judge Bartlett err in holding Judge Jacobsâ€™ order was valid and enforceable,
  notwithstanding it was not filed until after Judge Jacobsâ€™ death?
2. Did
  Judge Jacobs err in ruling Taylor was prohibited from representing Wife?
 
1.Â  JUDGE
  BARTLETTâ€™S ORDER
Wife contends
  Judge Jacobsâ€™ order is void and that she is entitled to a new trial pursuant to
  this Courtâ€™s opinion in Christy v. Christy, 354 S.C. 203, 580 S.E.2d 444
  (2004), and Rule 63, SCRCP.Â  We disagree.Â   
Christy involved the interpretation of Rule 63, SCRCP, prior to its 2004 amendment.Â  In Christy, a family court judge (Judge Black) heard claims relating to a
  common law marriage but became incapacitated prior to signing an order.Â  A
  second family court judge (Judge Segars-Andrews) succeeded Judge Black, and
  denied the respondentâ€™s motion for a new trial pursuant to Rule 63, SCRCP.Â  Judge
  Segars-Andrews later signed an order, based in part on a draft order submitted
  to Judge Black.Â  The order found no common law marriage.Â  The Court of Appeals
  vacated Judge Segars-Andrewsâ€™ order, finding she erred in denying respondentâ€™s
  request for a new trial following Judge Blackâ€™s incapacity; the Court of
  Appeals remanded the common law marriage issue for a new determination.Â  Christy
    v. Christy, 347 S.C. 503, 556 S.E.2d 701 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  This Court affirmed
  as modified.Â  Christy, 354 S.C. 203, 580 S.E.2d 444.Â  Although we found no
  error in the Court of Appealsâ€™ analysis of Rule 63, SCRCP, we found the case was
  governed by another principle of state law, to wit, the principle that â€œ[u]ntil
  the paper has been delivered by the judge to the clerk of court, to be filed by
  him as an order in the case, it is subject to the control of the judge, and may
  be withdrawn at any time before such delivery.â€Â  Christy, 354 S.C. at
  206, 580 S.E.2d at 446.Â  No written order having been filed with the clerk of
  court prior to Judge Blackâ€™s incapacity, this Court held a new trial was
  required.Â   
Relying
  on Christy, Wife contends Judge Bartlett erred in denying her motion for
  a new trial.Â  We disagree.Â  At the time Christy was decided, Rule 63, SCRCP,
  provided:

	If by reason of death, sickness, or other disability, a judge
  before whom an action has been tried is unable to perform the duties to be
  performed by the court under these rules after a verdict is returned or
    findings of fact and conclusions of law are filed, then the resident judge
  of the circuit or any other judge having jurisdiction in the court in which the
  action was tried may perform those duties; but if such other judge is satisfied
  that he cannot perform those duties because he did not preside at the trial or
  for any other reason, he may in his discretion grant a new trial.

(emphasis
  supplied).Â  However, the year following our opinion in Christy, Rule 63
  was amended to conform to the requirements of Rule 63, FRCP.Â Â  It now reads:

	If at any time after a trial or hearing has been commenced, but 
	before
  the final order or judgment has been issued, the judge is unable to
  proceed, a successor judge shall be assigned. The successor judge may proceed
  upon certifying familiarity with the record and determining that the
  proceedings may be completed without prejudice to the parties. In a hearing or
  a trial without a jury, the successor judge shall, at the request of a party,
  recall any witness whose testimony is material and disputed and who is
  available to testify without undue burden. A successor judge may also provide
  for the recall of any witnesses.

(emphasis
  supplied).Â   
Judge
  Bartlett found the purpose of Rule 63 was to ensure that a proceeding which had
  started had been completed.Â  He further found that the 2004 amendments made two
  changes: 1) changing the language from filed to issued, and 2) removing the
  authority of the successor to grant a new trial.Â  He found under the unique
  facts of this case, that Judge Jacobs had completed the proceedings before him
  such that there was no need for a successor judge.Â  We agree.Â   
The
  purpose of Rule 63 is to ensure that a proceeding has been completed.Â  Here, it
  is clear both from Judge Jacobsâ€™ bench rulings, and the signed order that the
  hearing was complete.Â  Wifeâ€™s reliance upon Christy overlooks the
  amendment to Rule 63, and the deliberate inclusion of the language concerning
  when a final judgment or order has been â€œissued.â€Â  Given the specific language
  of the rule, it is not for this Court to attach a new meaning.Â  See Farnswoth
    v. Davis Heating and Air Cond., 367 S.E.2d 634, 627 S.E.2d 724 (2006); Maxwell
      v. Genez, 356 S.C. 617, 620, 591 S.E.2d 26, 27 (2003) (in interpreting the
  meaning of Rules of Civil Procedure, this Court applies the same rules of
  construction used to interpret statutes); State v. Muldrow, 348 S.C.
  264, 268, 559 S.E.2d 847, 849 (2002) (words of a statute must be given their
  plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to
  limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation). Â 
Under the very limited facts of this case, we find Judge Jacobsâ€™ order
  was â€œissuedâ€ after it was signed and sent to Counsel for filing.Â   
2.Â 
  DISQUALIFICATION OF ATTORNEY TAYLOR
Wife
  asserts Judge Jacobs erred in disqualifying attorney Taylor, contending Husband
  waived any right to complain about any alleged conflict on the part of Taylor.Â  Â We agree.Â Â  We find Husband was estopped to seek disqualification of Wifeâ€™s
  attorney where he waited for fifteen months after institution of the
  proceedings, at a time when Wife sought to have him held in contempt.Â  Cf.Â  Strickland v. Strickland, 375 S.C. 76, 650 S.E.2d 465 (2007) (one who
  delays unreasonably could be said to be estopped from asserting a claim if
  another has relied on that delay to his detriment).Â Â  Â Â 
In any
  event, we do not find that the prior representation by attorney Taylorâ€™s
  partner was substantially related to the present matter.Â  Townsend v.
    Townsend, 323 S.C. 309, 317, 474 S.E.2d 424, 429 (1996).Â  Accordingly, Judge
  Jacobs erred in disqualifying Wifeâ€™s attorney.
CONCLUSION
We
  affirm Judge Bartlettâ€™s order holding Judge Jacobsâ€™ order valid and
  enforceable.Â  However, we reverse Judge Jacobsâ€™ order disqualifying Wifeâ€™s
  attorney.
AFFIRMED
  IN PART, REVERSED IN PART.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  The appeals were transferred from the Court of
  Appeals to this Court pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â

title: Broach v. State
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD
  NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				William Broach, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Richland County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2008-MO-014
Submitted February 21, 2008 â€“ Filed March
  10, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Tommy Arthur Thomas, Tricia A. Blanchette, both of Tommy A.
  Thomas, PC, of Irmo, for Petitioner.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott; and
  Assistant Attorney General Brian T. Petrano, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â 
  We granted William Broach a belated direct appeal of his convictions and
  sentences for four counts of criminal sexual conduct with a minor, first degree,
  and one count of criminal sexual conduct with a minor, second degree.Â  He
  argues the trial court erred by:Â  (1) allowing the State to introduce his prior
  conviction for committing a lewd act on a minor during the cross-examination of
  his employer; and (2) relying on the Rape Shield statute in refusing to admit
  evidence that one of the victims was sexually abused by her stepfather. Â 
We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following
  authorities:Â  Issue 1: Â State
    v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989) (noting that an
  insubstantial error that does not affect the result of the trial is harmless
  where guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no
  other rational conclusion can be reached); Issue 2:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  16-3-659.1(1) (2003) (providing that specific instances of a victimâ€™s own
  sexual conduct is not admissible in criminal sexual conduct prosecutions); State
    v. Grovenstein, 340 S.C. 210, 219, 530 S.E.2d 406, 411 (Ct. App. 2000)
  (providing that evidence of a child witnessâ€™s prior sexual experience is
  â€œrelevant to demonstrate that the defendant is not necessarily the source of
  the victimâ€™sâ€ knowledge of sexual matters).

AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

title: Turner Construction Co., Inc. v. City of Spartanburg
text:
THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Turner
      Construction Co., Inc., Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				The City of
      Spartanburg, William Barnet III, in his capacity as Mayor of the City of
      Spartanburg, Robert Reeder, Robert â€œBobâ€ Allen, Lewis Mills, and Linda Dogan,
      each in their capacity as Members of the Spartanburg City Council,
      Renaissance Park Hotel, LLC, Bridgeview Capital Solutions, LLC, Marriott
      Hotel Services, Inc., Calvary Consulting, Inc., Walden Leasing, Inc. d/b/a
      Walden Construction Services, Corrosion Consultants, Inc. d/b/a CCI Flooring
      Systems, The Circle Group, LLC, Hodge Contract Carpets, Inc. d/b/a Hodge
      Carpets, Milliken & Company, Video Systems of Carolina, Carolina
      Applicators, Inc., Defendants,
				of whom City of
      Spartanburg is Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Spartanburg County
Â J. Mark Hayes II, Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2008-MO-016 

Heard November 1, 2007 â€“ Filed March 24,
  2008
VACATED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Thomas H. Coker, Jr. and Joel
  M. Bondurant, Jr., both of Haynsworth Sinkler Boyd, of Greenville, and John
  Dean Marshall, Jr., of Sutherland Asbill & Brennan, of Atlanta, for
  Appellant.
				Frank H. Gibbes III and
  Stephanie Holmes Burton, both of Gibbes Burton, and H. Spencer King, of the Ward
  Law Firm, all of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
				Charles H. McDonald and
  Daniel T. Brailsford, both of Robinson McFadden & Moore, of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae American Subcontractors Association of the Carolinas.
				L. Franklin Elmore, of Elmore
  & Wall, of Greenville, for Amicus Curiae Carolinas Associated General
  Contractors.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â Â Â Â  The
  general contractor working on a city construction project brought several
  claims against the city for allegedly failing to comply with a statutory bond
  requirement for contractors working on public projects.Â  Recognizing the court
  of appealsâ€™ opinion in Sloan Construction Co., Inc. v. Southco Grassing,
    Inc., 368 S.C. 523, 629 S.E.2d 372 (Ct. App. 2006), the trial court granted
  the cityâ€™s motion to dismiss the contractorâ€™s breach of statute claim on the
  grounds that the bond statute did not give rise to a private right of action by
  the contractor against the city.Â  This appeal followed.Â   
We vacate
  the trial courtâ€™s decision pursuant to this Courtâ€™s decision in Sloan
    Construction Co., Inc. v. Southco Grassing, Inc., Op.
  No. 26462 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed March 24, 2008) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 13 at 32) (holding that the governmentâ€™s failure to comply with statutory bonding requirements
  in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-6-250 (Supp. 2006) gives rise to both a negligence claim
  and a third-party beneficiary breach of contract claim by the subcontractor
  against the government).Â  Accordingly, we remand the case to the trial court
  for a determination of whether the city breached a statutory or contractual
  duty owed to the contractor pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-6-250.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice Alexander S. Macaulay,
  concur.

title: Johnson v. State
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Russell O.
      Johnson, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â Diane Schafer Goodstein, Post-Conviction Relief Judge

Memorandum Opinion No.Â  2008-MO-017
Submitted March 19, 2008 â€“ Filed March 24,
  2008Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Deputy
  Chief Appellate Defender Wanda H. Carter, of South Carolina Commission on
  Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney
  General S. Prentiss Counts, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  Petitioner pled guilty to armed robbery
  and first-degree
  burglary and was sentenced to concurrent terms of eighteen yearsâ€™
  imprisonment.Â  No direct appeal was taken.Â   
Petitioner filed an application for
  post-conviction relief (PCR) alleging he was
  not advised of his right to a direct appeal.Â  At the PCR hearing, no testimony
  was presented on this issue, and the State consented to allowing petitioner to
  have a belated appeal.Â  The PCR judge granted petitioner a belated review of
  his direct appeal issues, finding the uncontroverted evidence showed petitioner
  was not advised of his right to appeal.Â  Petitioner now seeks a writ of
  certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s order and has filed a brief addressing his
  direct appeal issues pursuant to White v. State, 263 S.C. 110, 208
  S.E.2d 35 (1974).
â€œ[A]bsent
  extraordinary circumstances, there is no constitutional requirement that a
  defendant be informed of a right to a direct appeal from a guilty plea.â€Â  Weathers
    v. State, 319 S.C. 59, 459 S.E.2d 838 (1995).Â  Counsel has a duty to advise
  a defendant about an appeal when there is reason to think either: (1) a
  rational defendant would want to appeal; or (2) this particular defendant
  reasonably demonstrated that he was interested in appealing.Â  Roe v.
    Flores-Ortega, 528 U.S. 470, 120 S.Ct. 1029, 145 L.Ed.2d 985 (2000).Â  In
  determining whether a rational defendant would have desired an appeal, â€œthe
  court must consider such factors as whether the defendant received the sentence
  bargained for as a part of the plea and whether the plea expressly reserved or
  waived some or all appeal rights.â€Â  Flores-Ortega, supra.Â  
 
We
  find petitioner failed to show he was entitled to be advised of his right to a
  direct appeal.Â  Caprood v. State, 338 S.C. 103, 525 S.E.2d 514 (2000).Â  No
  objections were made at petitionerâ€™s guilty plea hearing, petitioner received the
  recommended sentence, and there was no evidence presented at the PCR hearing
  that petitioner inquired about an appeal.Â  Flores-Ortega, supra; Weathers, supra.Â  Accordingly, the PCR judgeâ€™s order granting petitioner a belated
  appeal is  
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  MOORE, J., not participating.
